docs.headline: Personal Health
docs.lead_paragraph: WHAT do women want to know about their health, the possibilities of losing it and the ways of preserving it? As the recipient of dozens of letters each month from readers of this column, and as a frequent lecturer on health to large audiences of women throughout the United States, I am regularly besieged by queries about women's health issues.WHAT do women want to know about their health, the possibilities of losing it and the ways of preserving it? As the recipient of dozens of letters each month from readers of this column, and as a frequent lecturer on health to large audiences of women throughout the United States, I am regularly besieged by queries about women's health issues. | WHAT do women want to know about their health, the possibilities of losing it and the ways of preserving it?    As the recipient of dozens of letters each month from readers of this column, and as a frequent lecturer on health to large audiences of... | Jane E Brody column answers common questions from readers on women's health issues; offers basic tips for a healthy lifestyle (M) |

docs.headline: The Brain, in Exquisite Detail The Brain, in Exquisite Detail
docs.lead_paragraph: Undertaking thousands of hours of work, researchers are working to create an interactive database of a healthy brain’s structure and activity, the first of its kind.Undertaking thousands of hours of work, researchers are working to create an interactive database of a healthy brain’s structure and activity, the first of its kind. | Researchers at Washington Univ in St Louis are creating three-dimensional, interactive map of working human brain, with detail to one and a half cubic millimeters; research is to be used to create baseline database that does not yet exist in neuroscience and will be made available online; effort is part of Human Connectome Project, five-year effort supported by National Institutes of Health (Series: The Map Makers). |

docs.headline: A Busy Doctor’s Right Hand, Ever Ready to Type A Busy Doctor’s Right Hand
docs.lead_paragraph: Scribes have entered the scene in clinics and operating rooms, liberating physicians from the constant note-taking that modern electronic health records systems demand.Scribes have entered the scene in clinics and operating rooms, liberating physicians from the constant note-taking that modern electronic health records systems demand. | Hundreds of clinics and emergency rooms are beginning to employ physician scribes, professionals who shadow doctors and keep patient records, allowing doctors to focus on care rather than clerical work. |

docs.headline: A Solution That Now Looks Crazy A Solution That Now Looks Crazy
docs.lead_paragraph: The psychiatrist E. Fuller Torrey offers an unflinching look at how grand intentions for fixing the treatment of severe mental illness went terribly wrong.The psychiatrist E. Fuller Torrey offers an unflinching look at how grand intentions for fixing the treatment of severe mental illness went terribly wrong. | Richard A Friedman reviews book American Psychosis: How the Federal Government Destroyed the Mental Illness Treatment System by E Fuller Torrey. |

docs.headline: W.H.O. May Begin Webcast of Health Ministers’ Meeting
docs.lead_paragraph: A move would allow health campaigners and journalists from many poor countries to at least watch the annual meeting, which considers questions of life and death.A move would allow health campaigners and journalists from many poor countries to at least watch the annual meeting, which considers questions of life and death. | World Health Organization, responding to angry letter published in a British medical journal, says it may soon start streaming its annual meeting of world’s health ministers on the web, where it can be viewed by health campaigners and journalists from poor countries who cannot afford to attend. |

docs.headline: Beings Not Made for Space Beings Not Made for Space
docs.lead_paragraph: Swelled heads, atrophied legs, radiation threats — space takes a toll on the human body, and some health problems still elude doctors more than 50 years after the first spaceflight.Swelled heads, atrophied legs, radiation threats — space takes a toll on the human body, and some health problems still elude doctors more than 50 years after the first spaceflight. | Sending humans into space for long periods of time poses litany of health problems, from swollen head and atrophied limbs to exposure to radiation; proposed NASA mission to send astronauts to Mars some time after 2030, trip that would take 2.5 years, or nearly six time current standard tour, has scientists racing to find solutions. |

docs.headline: Blazing Trails in Brain Science Blazing Trails in Brain Science
docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Thomas R. Insel’s twisted path to his role as director of the National Institute of Mental Health is a tour of where psychiatric science has been, where it’s going and why.Dr. Thomas R. Insel’s twisted path to his role as director of the National Institute of Mental Health is a tour of where psychiatric science has been, where it’s going and why. | Profile of Dr Thomas R Insel, brain scientist who runs the National Institute of Mental Health; Insel's twisting path to position traces development of psychiatric science; his tenure spans nearly half century and coincides with contentious top-down overhaul of field. |

docs.headline: Debating Evolution and Dealing With Climate Change Debating Evolution and Dealing With Climate Change
docs.lead_paragraph: Recent developments in health and science news. This week: A deadly bird flu in China causes alarm and researchers suggest revising guideline on intervention during labor.Recent developments in health and science news. This week: A deadly bird flu in China causes alarm and researchers suggest revising guideline on intervention during labor. | The Week column; experts say that new and more lethal strain of avian influenza, known as H7N9, is surging through China and has infected 300 people, a quarter of whom have died; other significant news in medicine and science highlighted. |

docs.headline: The Tall and the Small The Tall and the Small
docs.lead_paragraph: Though there has long been a popular assumption that taller people are healthier and likely to live longer, recent studies suggest the opposite may be true.Though there has long been a popular assumption that taller people are healthier and likely to live longer, recent studies suggest the opposite may be true. | Science Q&A on whether size affects life expectancy in humans as it does in dogs. |

docs.headline: Clues to a Very Old Extinction and Pizza for War Zones
docs.lead_paragraph: Science and health news from the past week, including a mass extinction 252 million years ago, and vaccines and pizzas that don’t spoil.Science and health news from the past week, including a mass extinction 252 million years ago, and vaccines and pizzas that don’t spoil. | The Week column; researchers studying volcanic ash to date fossils formed by extinction event 252 million years ago determine that entire episode lasted just 60,000 years; other notable developments in science and medicine highlighted. |

docs.headline: Out of Siberian Ice, a Virus Revived Out of Siberian Ice, a Virus Revived
docs.lead_paragraph: A team of researchers has found something new, with potential implications for evolutionary theory and health, in permafrost more than 30,000 years old.A team of researchers has found something new, with potential implications for evolutionary theory and health, in permafrost more than 30,000 years old. | Team of researchers has retrieved 30,000-year-old virus out of Siberian permafrost that remains capable of infecting amoebas; though virus is not threat to humans, its viability raises possibility that disease-causing viruses may also be lurking in permafrost; team describes its findings in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. |

docs.headline: Book Review: ‘Ending Medical Reversal’ Laments Flip-Flopping Treatment for Medical Whiplash
docs.lead_paragraph: Ever-changing advice on treatment and care is demoralizing both doctors and patients, the authors claim.Ever-changing advice on treatment and care is demoralizing both doctors and patients, the authors claim. | Dr Abigail Zuger reviews book Ending Medical Reversal: Improving Outcomes, Saving Lives by Dr Vinayak K Prasad. |

docs.headline: Gaining Insight Into Some Itches Neurology: Study Suggests Path to Understanding Itches
docs.lead_paragraph: Itches caused by the lightest of touches are created by a dedicated neural pathway, a new study suggests.Itches caused by the lightest of touches are created by a dedicated neural pathway, a new study suggests. | Dr Quifu Ma study in journal Science concludes dedicated neural pathway is responsible for itching caused by light touch; finding may prove useful in understanding chronic itching attached to some medical conditions. |

docs.headline: To Prevent Malaria in Humans, Scientists Try Protecting Pigs Livestock May Become Defense Against Malaria
docs.lead_paragraph: An experimental mosquito-killer for livestock may help prevent the transmission of the disease to humans.An experimental mosquito-killer for livestock may help prevent the transmission of the disease to humans. | Scientists have begun initiative to give deworming medication containing ivermectin to livestock in places affected by mosquito-borne diseases including malaria and yellow fever and chiungunya virus; research shows mosquitoes die after drinking blood of medicated humans or animals. |

docs.headline: Should Same-Sex Couples Receive Fertility Benefits? Lesbians’ Tougher Fertility Test
docs.lead_paragraph: Many insurance companies that cover infertility treatments for heterosexual couples will not reimburse treatment costs for same-sex couples.Many insurance companies that cover infertility treatments for heterosexual couples will not reimburse treatment costs for same-sex couples. |

docs.headline: Small Towns Face Rising Suicide Rates Deadly Isolation
docs.lead_paragraph: People living in rural areas kill themselves far more often than those in urban settings. One reason: poor access to mental health care.People living in rural areas kill themselves far more often than those in urban settings. One reason: poor access to mental health care. | Suicide rates in rural areas of United States are higher than in rest of country, due to combination of isolation, lower incomes, lack of access to mental health care and values stressing self-sufficiency; volunteers and rural health practices have begun effort to offer mental health services and encourage people to seek help. |

docs.headline: Some Older Patients Are Treated Not Wisely, but Too Much Overtreated Patients, Underwhelming Results
docs.lead_paragraph: Older adults with diabetes and other chronic conditions should be treated less aggressively than they commonly are, some experts say.Older adults with diabetes and other chronic conditions should be treated less aggressively than they commonly are, some experts say. | Mounting body of evidence suggests older adults with diabetes should receive less aggressive treatment than they commonly do; medical profession, however, has proved resistant to message, fearing consequences of under-treating patients more than over-treatment. |

docs.headline: When to Ignore a Promise to ‘Never Put Me in a Home’ A Plan for the Future Perfect
docs.lead_paragraph: Directives about how people want to be cared for at the end of their lives are often ignored, overlooked, lost — or even incomprehensible.Directives about how people want to be cared for at the end of their lives are often ignored, overlooked, lost — or even incomprehensible. |

docs.headline: New Treatment Slows an Epidemic of Sleeping Sickness Successful Double Team on Sleeping Slckness
docs.lead_paragraph: Cases of the disease declined among Ugandans after researchers began treating cattle.Cases of the disease declined among Ugandans after researchers began treating cattle. | Initiative to fight sleeping sickness in Uganda by treating cattle with anti-parasitic drugs and insecticides cut cattle infections, which lead to human ones, by 75 percent. |

docs.headline: Artificial Patients, Real Learning Artificial Patients, Real Learning
docs.lead_paragraph: Rubber and plastic dummies that have skin and internal organs with a realistic feel are providing blood-and-guts training for operations.Rubber and plastic dummies that have skin and internal organs with a realistic feel are providing blood-and-guts training for operations. | Technological advances in areas including computing, materials and 3-D printing are enabling creation of amazingly realistic medical training dummies and simulators; cutting-edge realism greatly helps learning process of new doctors. |

docs.headline: Hollywood in the Operating Room
docs.lead_paragraph: Surgeons at Massachusetts General Hospital have four minutes to save this gunshot wound victim. So how do residents learn such a risky procedure? With a little help from Hollywood.Surgeons at Massachusetts General Hospital have four minutes to save this gunshot wound victim. So how do residents learn such a risky procedure? With a little help from Hollywood. |

docs.headline: Ask Well: The Health Benefits of Meditation
docs.lead_paragraph: There are many types of meditation, and research shows the effects vary tremendously among individuals.There are many types of meditation, and research shows the effects vary tremendously among individuals. |

docs.headline: Ask Well: Ebola and Sex
docs.lead_paragraph: There is now one clear-cut case of transmission of the Ebola virus through semen, prompting officials to advise that male survivors use condoms, possibly indefinitely.There is now one clear-cut case of transmission of the Ebola virus through semen, prompting officials to advise that male survivors use condoms, possibly indefinitely. |

docs.headline: Ask Well: Do Indoor Plants Improve Our Health?
docs.lead_paragraph: Flowers and plants in the home may have benefits for mind and body, some small studies suggest.Flowers and plants in the home may have benefits for mind and body, some small studies suggest. |

docs.headline: Sleeping In Feels So Good, but May Be Unhealthy Behavior: Side Effects of Sleeping In
docs.lead_paragraph: A new study provides evidence of a higher risk of heart disease and diabetes in people who sleep later on weekends.A new study provides evidence of a higher risk of heart disease and diabetes in people who sleep later on weekends. |

docs.headline: Endangered White Rhino Nola Dies at San Diego Zoo Safari Park
docs.lead_paragraph: Nola was euthanized after her health deteriorated because of an infection, leaving just three known northern white rhinos, which live under armed guard in Kenya.Nola was euthanized after her health deteriorated because of an infection, leaving just three known northern white rhinos, which live under armed guard in Kenya. |

docs.headline: A Step Closer to the Defeat of Polio Polio’s Defeat Is Getting Closer
docs.lead_paragraph: The last known Type 3 polio case occurred three years ago, which means that type has most likely disappeared for good.The last known Type 3 polio case occurred three years ago, which means that type has most likely disappeared for good. | World Health Organization reports it has been three years since last detection of Type 3 wild polio virus anywhere on globe, signifying subtype has likely been eradicated, and world may be one step closer to eliminating disease. |

docs.headline: Ask Well: Do Cranberries Offer Health Benefits?
docs.lead_paragraph: Cranberries contain chemical compounds called proanthocyanidins that may have benefits throughout the body.Cranberries contain chemical compounds called proanthocyanidins that may have benefits throughout the body. |

docs.headline: Changes Coming for Health Care in China and Cuba Changes, Perhaps Not for the Better
docs.lead_paragraph: The two countries are models of effective public health policies, but some planned changes may not be for the better.The two countries are models of effective public health policies, but some planned changes may not be for the better. | China and Cuba have led world in public health intervention, but experts are questioning whether some policy changes may have negative effects; some worry end to China's one-child policy may strain hospitals, while Cuba's normalized relations with West may lead to loss of medical talent. |

docs.headline: 3,988,076: The Number of U.S. Births in 2014 3,988,076: The Number of U.S. Births in 2014
docs.lead_paragraph: The total was 1 percent higher than in 2013, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. The teenage birthrate dropped 9 percent.The total was 1 percent higher than in 2013, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. The teenage birthrate dropped 9 percent. | National Center for Health Statistics reports number of births in 2014 rose to 3,988,076, 1 percent higher than in 2013. |

docs.headline: Letters to the Editor
docs.lead_paragraph: Readers react to articles in Science Times.Readers react to articles in Science Times. |

docs.headline: U.S. Becomes More Vulnerable to Tropical Diseases Like Zika Newly Opening Door to Tropical Diseases
docs.lead_paragraph: A changing climate and human factors are sending viruses like Zika toward the United States.A changing climate and human factors are sending viruses like Zika toward the United States. | Tropical diseases are spreading northward, to United States and elsewhere, driven by climate change; scientists say range of factors determine whether sporadic episodes of mosquito- and tick-borne illnesses will develop into epidemics. |

docs.headline: Healthful School Lunches Mean Healthier Students Healthier Lunches and Students
docs.lead_paragraph: The Healthy Hunger-Free Kids Act, which mandated increased availability of whole grains, vegetables and fruits at schools, means children are eating healthier, a study shows.The Healthy Hunger-Free Kids Act, which mandated increased availability of whole grains, vegetables and fruits at schools, means children are eating healthier, a study shows. |

docs.headline: Growing Support Among Experts for Zika Advice to Delay Pregnancy Delaying Pregnancy Until Zika Moves On
docs.lead_paragraph: Infectious diseases experts say the approach could work, but others see it as unrealistic in areas where access to contraception and abortions is limited.Infectious diseases experts say the approach could work, but others see it as unrealistic in areas where access to contraception and abortions is limited. | Advice from health officials that women in countries affected by Zika virus delay pregnancy until outbreak is under control has been derided by many as unrealistic, particularly for poor women in country where abortion is illegal and contraception often unavailable; but some experts say delaying pregnancy long enough for population to build immunity may save newborns from disease's worst effects. |

response.headline: The Brain, in Exquisite Detail The Brain, in Exquisite Detail
response.lead_paragraph: Undertaking thousands of hours of work, researchers are working to create an interactive database of a healthy brain’s structure and activity, the first of its kind.Undertaking thousands of hours of work, researchers are working to create an interactive database of a healthy brain’s structure and activity, the first of its kind. | Researchers at Washington Univ in St Louis are creating three-dimensional, interactive map of working human brain, with detail to one and a half cubic millimeters; research is to be used to create baseline database that does not yet exist in neuroscience and will be made available online; effort is part of Human Connectome Project, five-year effort supported by National Institutes of Health (Series: The Map Makers). |

response.headline: A Busy Doctor’s Right Hand, Ever Ready to Type A Busy Doctor’s Right Hand
response.lead_paragraph: Scribes have entered the scene in clinics and operating rooms, liberating physicians from the constant note-taking that modern electronic health records systems demand.Scribes have entered the scene in clinics and operating rooms, liberating physicians from the constant note-taking that modern electronic health records systems demand. | Hundreds of clinics and emergency rooms are beginning to employ physician scribes, professionals who shadow doctors and keep patient records, allowing doctors to focus on care rather than clerical work. |

response.headline: A Solution That Now Looks Crazy A Solution That Now Looks Crazy
response.lead_paragraph: The psychiatrist E. Fuller Torrey offers an unflinching look at how grand intentions for fixing the treatment of severe mental illness went terribly wrong.The psychiatrist E. Fuller Torrey offers an unflinching look at how grand intentions for fixing the treatment of severe mental illness went terribly wrong. | Richard A Friedman reviews book American Psychosis: How the Federal Government Destroyed the Mental Illness Treatment System by E Fuller Torrey. |

response.headline: W.H.O. May Begin Webcast of Health Ministers’ Meeting
response.lead_paragraph: A move would allow health campaigners and journalists from many poor countries to at least watch the annual meeting, which considers questions of life and death.A move would allow health campaigners and journalists from many poor countries to at least watch the annual meeting, which considers questions of life and death. | World Health Organization, responding to angry letter published in a British medical journal, says it may soon start streaming its annual meeting of world’s health ministers on the web, where it can be viewed by health campaigners and journalists from poor countries who cannot afford to attend. |

response.headline: Beings Not Made for Space Beings Not Made for Space
response.lead_paragraph: Swelled heads, atrophied legs, radiation threats — space takes a toll on the human body, and some health problems still elude doctors more than 50 years after the first spaceflight.Swelled heads, atrophied legs, radiation threats — space takes a toll on the human body, and some health problems still elude doctors more than 50 years after the first spaceflight. | Sending humans into space for long periods of time poses litany of health problems, from swollen head and atrophied limbs to exposure to radiation; proposed NASA mission to send astronauts to Mars some time after 2030, trip that would take 2.5 years, or nearly six time current standard tour, has scientists racing to find solutions. |

response.headline: Blazing Trails in Brain Science Blazing Trails in Brain Science
response.lead_paragraph: Dr. Thomas R. Insel’s twisted path to his role as director of the National Institute of Mental Health is a tour of where psychiatric science has been, where it’s going and why.Dr. Thomas R. Insel’s twisted path to his role as director of the National Institute of Mental Health is a tour of where psychiatric science has been, where it’s going and why. | Profile of Dr Thomas R Insel, brain scientist who runs the National Institute of Mental Health; Insel's twisting path to position traces development of psychiatric science; his tenure spans nearly half century and coincides with contentious top-down overhaul of field. |

response.headline: Debating Evolution and Dealing With Climate Change Debating Evolution and Dealing With Climate Change
response.lead_paragraph: Recent developments in health and science news. This week: A deadly bird flu in China causes alarm and researchers suggest revising guideline on intervention during labor.Recent developments in health and science news. This week: A deadly bird flu in China causes alarm and researchers suggest revising guideline on intervention during labor. | The Week column; experts say that new and more lethal strain of avian influenza, known as H7N9, is surging through China and has infected 300 people, a quarter of whom have died; other significant news in medicine and science highlighted. |

response.headline: The Tall and the Small The Tall and the Small
response.lead_paragraph: Though there has long been a popular assumption that taller people are healthier and likely to live longer, recent studies suggest the opposite may be true.Though there has long been a popular assumption that taller people are healthier and likely to live longer, recent studies suggest the opposite may be true. | Science Q&A on whether size affects life expectancy in humans as it does in dogs. |

response.headline: Clues to a Very Old Extinction and Pizza for War Zones
response.lead_paragraph: Science and health news from the past week, including a mass extinction 252 million years ago, and vaccines and pizzas that don’t spoil.Science and health news from the past week, including a mass extinction 252 million years ago, and vaccines and pizzas that don’t spoil. | The Week column; researchers studying volcanic ash to date fossils formed by extinction event 252 million years ago determine that entire episode lasted just 60,000 years; other notable developments in science and medicine highlighted. |

response.headline: Out of Siberian Ice, a Virus Revived Out of Siberian Ice, a Virus Revived
response.lead_paragraph: A team of researchers has found something new, with potential implications for evolutionary theory and health, in permafrost more than 30,000 years old.A team of researchers has found something new, with potential implications for evolutionary theory and health, in permafrost more than 30,000 years old. | Team of researchers has retrieved 30,000-year-old virus out of Siberian permafrost that remains capable of infecting amoebas; though virus is not threat to humans, its viability raises possibility that disease-causing viruses may also be lurking in permafrost; team describes its findings in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. |

response.headline: Gaining Insight Into Some Itches Neurology: Study Suggests Path to Understanding Itches
response.lead_paragraph: Itches caused by the lightest of touches are created by a dedicated neural pathway, a new study suggests.Itches caused by the lightest of touches are created by a dedicated neural pathway, a new study suggests. | Dr Quifu Ma study in journal Science concludes dedicated neural pathway is responsible for itching caused by light touch; finding may prove useful in understanding chronic itching attached to some medical conditions. |

response.headline: To Prevent Malaria in Humans, Scientists Try Protecting Pigs Livestock May Become Defense Against Malaria
response.lead_paragraph: An experimental mosquito-killer for livestock may help prevent the transmission of the disease to humans.An experimental mosquito-killer for livestock may help prevent the transmission of the disease to humans. | Scientists have begun initiative to give deworming medication containing ivermectin to livestock in places affected by mosquito-borne diseases including malaria and yellow fever and chiungunya virus; research shows mosquitoes die after drinking blood of medicated humans or animals. |

response.headline: Should Same-Sex Couples Receive Fertility Benefits? Lesbians’ Tougher Fertility Test
response.lead_paragraph: Many insurance companies that cover infertility treatments for heterosexual couples will not reimburse treatment costs for same-sex couples.Many insurance companies that cover infertility treatments for heterosexual couples will not reimburse treatment costs for same-sex couples. |

response.headline: Small Towns Face Rising Suicide Rates Deadly Isolation
response.lead_paragraph: People living in rural areas kill themselves far more often than those in urban settings. One reason: poor access to mental health care.People living in rural areas kill themselves far more often than those in urban settings. One reason: poor access to mental health care. | Suicide rates in rural areas of United States are higher than in rest of country, due to combination of isolation, lower incomes, lack of access to mental health care and values stressing self-sufficiency; volunteers and rural health practices have begun effort to offer mental health services and encourage people to seek help. |

response.headline: Some Older Patients Are Treated Not Wisely, but Too Much Overtreated Patients, Underwhelming Results
response.lead_paragraph: Older adults with diabetes and other chronic conditions should be treated less aggressively than they commonly are, some experts say.Older adults with diabetes and other chronic conditions should be treated less aggressively than they commonly are, some experts say. | Mounting body of evidence suggests older adults with diabetes should receive less aggressive treatment than they commonly do; medical profession, however, has proved resistant to message, fearing consequences of under-treating patients more than over-treatment. |

response.headline: New Treatment Slows an Epidemic of Sleeping Sickness Successful Double Team on Sleeping Slckness
response.lead_paragraph: Cases of the disease declined among Ugandans after researchers began treating cattle.Cases of the disease declined among Ugandans after researchers began treating cattle. | Initiative to fight sleeping sickness in Uganda by treating cattle with anti-parasitic drugs and insecticides cut cattle infections, which lead to human ones, by 75 percent. |

response.headline: Artificial Patients, Real Learning Artificial Patients, Real Learning
response.lead_paragraph: Rubber and plastic dummies that have skin and internal organs with a realistic feel are providing blood-and-guts training for operations.Rubber and plastic dummies that have skin and internal organs with a realistic feel are providing blood-and-guts training for operations. | Technological advances in areas including computing, materials and 3-D printing are enabling creation of amazingly realistic medical training dummies and simulators; cutting-edge realism greatly helps learning process of new doctors. |

response.headline: Growing Support Among Experts for Zika Advice to Delay Pregnancy Delaying Pregnancy Until Zika Moves On
response.lead_paragraph: Infectious diseases experts say the approach could work, but others see it as unrealistic in areas where access to contraception and abortions is limited.Infectious diseases experts say the approach could work, but others see it as unrealistic in areas where access to contraception and abortions is limited. | Advice from health officials that women in countries affected by Zika virus delay pregnancy until outbreak is under control has been derided by many as unrealistic, particularly for poor women in country where abortion is illegal and contraception often unavailable; but some experts say delaying pregnancy long enough for population to build immunity may save newborns from disease's worst effects. |
